Hey, Bill. Glad to hear from you again.
Long time since JavaOne and JavaWorld.

It's good to know that I wasn't the only one confused by the
overloading of the word "test". My next major hurdle is getting
a good handle on the process of TDD -- the paradigm shift
looks as big as shyifting into O-O thinking. (I seem to be having
as much trouble doing it, at least.)

Altima looks pretty interesting. I like the separation of reporting
from testing, and the runpath idea. The short summary doesn't
really tell me what a recipe file is good for, though. I guess I need
to know more about the possible "run properties of a particular
suite", and why I would want to use them.

Most of all, I'm looking forward to understanding more about
how it "can help developers create unit and conformance tests".

...And to understanding more about how to do TDD well in the
first place.

It's funny, on my last project I had the sudden realization that
"document-driven design" (requirements gathering, really) was
the right way to go. And it worked. It did a dynamite job of
gathering the requirements and generating the program's user
guide, in tandem with the design notes. So, even while the design
was evolving, I knew where I needed to go. (And as additional
questions came up, I had a place to record the answers.)

The interesting thing, though, is that while the process "works",
I would have a very difficult time describing *how* it works.
TDD seems a lot like that. It's something that works well when
you really understand it, but something that at the same time
appears to be very difficult to describe!

"billvenners " wrote:

>  Eric,
>
> > Somehow, I was under the impression that each test
> > in a test case started with a "clean slate" -- that the
> > setup code was re-run for each test method.
> >
> > But that doesn't appear to be the case. The test object
> > created during setup turned out to be reused for
> > subsequent tests in the test case, which caused problems
> > arising from old state, until I figured it out.
> >
> > Now, for performance, it only makes sense that a fixture
> > would be reused for each test in a test case class. So I'm
> > not suggesting that the implementation is wrong.
> >
> For a long time my impression was that an instance of TestCase is
> created, and all test methods are invoked on that same instance. The
> reason I thought this was that it seemed like the natural way to do
> it to me, plus it justified the existence of setUp. Given fixtures
> are usually instance data, a method like setUp is needed only if you
> are going to reuse the same instance on multiple test methods, and
> some of those test methods may destroy the fixture.
>
> While looking through JUnit's source code, I discovered that JUnit
> creates a new instance for each test method when it runs. So then I
> got to wondering what setUp was really there for, because if you are
> going to create a new TestCase instance for each test method, then
> you could use the constructor to initialized the fixture.
>
> Last year I created a testing toolkit similar to JUnit, Artima
> SuiteRunner, that also serves as a JUnit runner to run JUnit test
> suites. What I ended up doing in SuiteRunner was running all the test
> methods on the same Suite instance, calling setUpFixture and
> tearDownFixture before and after each test method. SuiteRunner is
> free and open source:
>
> http://www.artima.com/suiterunner/
>
> I'm curious if anyone out there has some kind of dependency on
> JUnit's approach of creating a new TestCase instance for each test
> method.
>
> > But I read the docs at the main site, and I've been following
> > these threads for quite a while, and still I had a dead-wrong
> > impression of what's going on.
> >
> > For example, in the FAQ, q2 "How do I use a text fixture?"
> > says:
> >    "Each test runs in its own test fixture to isolate tests from the
>
> >    changes made by other tests. Because the tests are isolated,
> >    they can be run in any order.... The JUnit framework
> >    automatically invokes the setUp() method before each test is
> >    run and the tearDown() method after each test is run."
> >
> > Now for "test", I was reading "test *method*". As in testX(),
> > testY(). But my recent epiphany suggests that I should have
> > been reading it as "test *case*", as in "test-case class". And
> > since the example shows a single test case class, with multiple
> > test methods in it, it was easy to make that assumption.
> >
> > Note:
> > In general, I'm not much fond of the name, "TestCase", because
> > to me that represents a single test. Since a TestCase class can
> > actually have multiple test methods, the name "TestFixture" is
> > probably more appropriate. But be that as it may...
> >
> > It appears to me that the word "test" is badly overloaded in the
> > docs, meaning at various times, test method, test case, and
> > potentially even test suite.
> >
> > The best way to eliminate confusion that I can see is to do a
> > global search on "test ", and replace with one of the hyphenated
> > words "test-method", "test-case", or "test-suite", as appropriate.
>
> I too was confused by JUnit's overloading of the word test. There's a
> Test interface, and a both TestCase and a TestSuite implement Tests.
> So it looks conceptually like test cases and test suites are two
> kinds of tests. But test methods also seem to be tests. I wasn't sure
> what JUnit's notion of the concept of "test" was by looking at the
> API or reading the articles.
>
> One thing I tried hard to do in SuiteRunner was have a clearly but
> abstractly defined notion of "test." The only place the word test
> shows up in the API is in testX, testY methods and 4 Reporter
> methods: testStarting, testSucceeded, testFailed, testAborted. A test
> method is one kind of conceptual test that can be reported via the 4
> Reporter methods, but not the only kind.
>
> I also tried to be clear about what a "suite" was. There's a class
> Suite that represents the concept of suite, which is simply a
> collection of conceptual tests. Typically people will subclass Suite
> and add test methods -- that's one kind of suite. But once again, it's
>
> not the only kind of Suite. I have a JUnitSuite internal to the
> package that I use to run JUnit test suites. That's another kind of
> conceptual suite that is represented by a sublcass of Suite.
>
